Award.AwardTitle: RAPID/Collaborative Research: Japan-U.S. Collaboration on the Seismic Performance of Reinforced Concrete Structures

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration: Reinforced concrete (RC) structures comprise most of the multi-family residential buildings in the U.S. and many other countries. When buildings are subjected to catastrophic events such as earthquakes, there is the need to assess their level of structural safety after the event. Structural assessment activities present two challenges - collecting high quality damage data and interpreting the acquired data in a meaningful and rational way - to produce estimates of the level of safety and residual strength of the inspected building. While advanced data acquisition systems are available to collect structural damage data, new methods are needed to analyze the collected data to assess structural performance. This Grant for Rapid Response Research (RAPID) will support a team of researchers from the University of Washington and the University of Nevada, Reno, to collaborate with researchers from Japanese universities on experimental research investigating the seismic performance of RC building systems. The experimental research will involve the dynamic testing of a full-scale, three-story RC building as part of the ongoing Tokyo Metropolitan Resilience Project (TMRP) supported in Japan by the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology and the National Research Institute for Earth Science and Disaster Resilience. The experiments will be conducted at the world's largest shake table, E-Defense in Miki, Japan, in December 2019. The main goal of this RAPID project is to acquire, process, and analyze dynamic response and damage data pertaining to both structural and non-structural elements of the building. The data will be collected using equipment recently acquired by the NSF-supported Natural Hazards Engineering Research Infrastructure (NHERI) RAPID Facility (https://rapid.designsafe-ci.org/) and the high-speed, high-resolution digital image correlation (DIC) integrated monitoring system recently developed at the University of Nevada, Reno. The processing and interpretation of this data will advance the state of knowledge and practice in post-earthquake structural assessments of buildings. The project will train two graduate students and several undergraduate students in structural integrity research and promote collaboration between Japanese and U.S. researchers. All collected data will be archived and made publicly available in the NSF-supported NHERI Data Depot (https://www.DesignSafe-ci.org/). Additionally, the results of this project will be disseminated via journal publications, conference presentations, a public webinar, and live broadcasts. This project contributes to NSF's role in the National Earthquake Hazards Reduction Program (NEHRP). <br/><br/>In this RAPID project, the Japanese and U.S. research team will investigate the seismic performance of a full-scale, three-story RC building system tested at the E-Defense shake table as part of the Japanese TMRP project. The key objectives of this collaborative project are to: (1) provide better understanding of dynamic response of RC buildings, (2) investigate the capabilities of new instrumentation to capture structural performance and damage data, and (3) evaluate current post-earthquake structural assessment procedures and use the acquired data to provide information for refinements. The collected data and structural assessment procedures will also help policymakers in the U.S., Japan, and other countries to plan retrofit efforts strategically and effectively.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
An overwhelming amount of building data were acquired throughout full-scale shake table tests, using high-resolution ultra high-density point clouds obtained at scan rates of more than 1 million points per second using Leica P50 and Leica RTC360 terrestrial Lidar scanners.

The collected lidar data were used to explore the damage features that can be extracted from a 3D point cloud which are important for post-disaster structural assessment purposes. More specifically, the project focused on lidar data processing and registration, estimation of residual displacements and inter-story drifts, concrete cracking and spalling identification and concrete cracking and spalling measurement. The main purpose was to develop best practice guidelines for data collection and to illustrate the potential that lidar data have with respect to the evaluation of damaged structures, paving the way for possible future research activities in this field.

This was achieved by analyzing a series of structural components in which lidar data were processed and analyzed to assess specific structural components. These cases have shown that point cloud data can indeed be processed to obtain measurements of global residual drifts or of the extent of visible damage (e.g., crack width, spalling). Displacements and damaged areas can be computed by comparing the point clouds collected before and after an event, but it was shown that meaningful measurements can also be obtained from individual scans, which is of more practical interest because in a real scenario (most likely) point clouds would only be collected after an earthquake.

The results obtained in this project clearly indicate that collecting post-disaster data using terrestrial lidar scanners has the potential to change the landscape creating a paradigm shift in how buildings are assessed. For instance, the use of lidar has the promise to lead to significantly more rapid and more detailed inspections, substantially reduced need of experts in the aftermath of natural disasters and greatly enhanced accuracy/consistency of the information collected.

Additionally, acquiring damage data using lidar significantly enhances the safety of the personnel conducting building inspection and data collection as scans of the outside of a structure can be conducted with high accuracy from a safe distance, and scans of the structure’s inside can also be conducted from a distance, once the scanners have been adequately set up. This minimizes the amount of time that inspectors are exposed to risks related to sudden post-earthquake collapses, induced for example by aftershocks.  

The results of this project have been presented at several webinars, summarized in conference and journal papers and all data have been archived and published in DesignSafe.
